discussion.content: it's important to remember that password cracking and brute forcing a password/attacks like dictionary ones are two completely different things.

In cryptanalysis and computer security, password cracking is the process of recovering passwords[1] from data that has been stored in or transmitted by a computer system in scrambled form. A common approach (brute-force attack) is to repeatedly try guesses for the password and to check them against an available cryptographic hash of the password.[2]

The purpose of password cracking might be to help a user recover a forgotten password (installing an entirely new password is less of a security risk, but it involves System Administration privileges), to gain unauthorized access to a system, or to act as a preventive measure whereby system administrators check for easily crackable passwords. On a file-by-file basis, password cracking is utilized to gain access to digital evidence to which a judge has allowed access, when a particular file's permissions are restricted.

comments.content: If a file with hashed values is the password file, the D should be correct.

discussion.content: I think that D is the wrong answer.

CVE’s common identifiers make it easier to share data across separate network security databases and tools, and provide a baseline for evaluating the coverage of an organization’s security tools. If a report from one of your security tools incorporates CVE Identifiers, you may then quickly and accurately access fix information in one or more separate CVE-compatible databases to remediate the problem.

So the CISO is looking the way to do improvements that can be made to the guides. Based on the answers, A is the BEST source of referense during the revision process.

Answer is B dummies... 

Internal security assessment reports are conducted for periodic assessment of systems and provide security recommendations for weaknesses in the network
Industry standards are more general hardening standards for security, not specific to your personal network. Why would you want to take general non specific standards over your personal assessments of what YOU KNOW IS WRONG IN YOUR NETWORK.
B - no questions asked

comments.content: your comment makes you sound childish, but i'd have to go with B or C as well, leaning toward B because C is so general.

"Why would you want to take general non specific standards over your personal assessments of what YOU KNOW IS WRONG IN YOUR NETWORK."
Because there may be issues that are known to the industry, that you have not yet encountered. Maybe you have a vulnerability, known to the industry, that has not yet been exploited, but could be exploited.

I agree that a CVE would not be useful to help write a hardening guide for your system. C makes sense but so does E... why wouldn't you just use the manufacturer's hardening guide to help write your own? If you've ever read a Cisco device hardening guide, it's EXACTLY what I would use to harden my own devices and could be heavily referenced to build local policy...

But industry standards may not always be as thorough as vendor recommendations. 
In the real world, I think I would consider both. 
But, for legal reasons, if I had to pick one, I think I would go with industry standards.
I would say C over E because vendors recommended implementation might not always meet industry regulations.

discussion.content:
I would lean more toward C.
"A. CVE db" would not directly help to improve about hardening guide ...

questions.question_text:
A Chief Information Security Officer (CISO is reviewing and revising system configuration and hardening guides that were developed internally and have been used several years to secure the organization's systems. The CISO knows improvements can be made to the guides.
Which of the following would be the BEST source of reference during the revision process?

discussion.content:
Going with the given answer.
Question asks to "compare documented access requirements to the access implemented within the file system"
We are comparing that access that is supposed to exist, to the access that does exist. 
"access implemented within the file system" is best revealed in the ACLs. This tells us the access that actually does exist.
"documented access requirements" would be shown in the data access policies, not the SRTM. The SRTM documents what is required for a system's security, that is really not the same as who needs what access.

comments.content: Wouldn't "A. Access control list" show us what is currently being allowed? It seems possible that the access policy is not being followed. But the ACL would show us exactly what is being done.
Sorry, meant B&F there, not E.

discussion.content: I believe the answer is B&E. Security requirements traceability matrix will provide the standard to be met, and access policy will show what we are currently allowing.

questions.question_text:
A systems administrator recently joined an organization and has been asked to perform a security assessment of controls on the organization's file servers, which contain client data from a number of sensitive systems. The administrator needs to compare documented access requirements to the access implemented within the file system.
Which of the following is MOST likely to be reviewed during the assessment? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: if anyone's wondering, the USB comment is there to completely distract you from the cloud aspect of this question.
I couldn't tell if this was cloud or a web solution that's installed on-premises. The phrase "web solution" really isn't specific enough. A web solution could be hosted internally, after all.

questions.question_text:
Security policies that are in place at an organization prohibit USB drives from being utilized across the entire enterprise, with adequate technical controls in place to block them. As a way to still be able to work from various locations on different computing resources, several sales staff members have signed up for a web- based storage solution without the consent of the IT department. However, the operations department is required to use the same service to transmit certain business partner documents.
Which of the following would BEST allow the IT department to monitor and control this behavior?

Legal counsel has notified the information security manager of a legal matter that will require the preservation of electronic records for 2000 sales force employees. Source records will be email, PC, network shares, and applications.
After all restrictions have been lifted, which of the following should the information manager review?

comments.content: Agreed, as usual the wording is terrible. The law is out of the equation, so it's Data Retention.
Yes it is confusingly phrased. AFTER legal has lifted the restrictions what do you do? Review the data retention policy to see what you can destroy and what still needs to be kept.

discussion.content: In this question the legal has been lifted so now you have to know how long to retain the information. Data Retention Policy
A legal hold is a process that an organization uses to preserve all forms of potentially relevant information when litigation is pending or reasonably anticipated.
